message_2:
Let $A$ be an abelian variety of dimension $g$ over a field $k$ of characteristic zero. The endomorphism ring $\text{End}(A)$ is a commutative subring of $\text{End}_{k}(V)$, where $V$ is the tangent space of $A$ at the identity element. Since $A$ has dimension $g$, the tangent space $V$ is a $g$-dimensional vector space over $k$. The endomorphisms of $V$ form a $k$-algebra isomorphic to the matrix algebra $M_g(k)$, consisting of $g \times g$ matrices with entries in $k$.

Now, consider the action of $\text{End}(A)$ on the tangent space $V$. Since $\text{End}(A)$ is a commutative subring of $\text{End}_{k}(V)$, it is also a commutative $k$-algebra. By the structure theorem for commutative semisimple algebras, $\text{End}(A)$ is isomorphic to a product of matrix algebras over division rings:

$$\text{End}(A) \cong M_{n_1}(D_1) \times \cdots \times M_{n_r}(D_r),$$

where $D_i$ are division rings that are finite-dimensional over their centers $F_i$, which are subfields of $k$. Since $\text{End}(A)$ is a subalgebra of $M_g(k)$, we have

$$\sum_{i=1}^r n_i^2 [F_i : k] \le g^2.$$

The maximum number of independent elements in $\text{End}(A)$ is the dimension of $\text{End}(A)$ as a $k$-vector space, which is given by

$$\dim_k \text{End}(A) = \sum_{i=1}^r n_i^2 [F_i : k].$$

To maximize this quantity, we want to maximize the sum of the squares of the degrees $n_i$ of the matrix algebras in the decomposition, subject to the constraint that the sum of the squares of the degrees times the field extensions $[F_i : k]$ is at most $g^2$. 

Since $[F_i : k] \ge 1$ for all $i$, the maximum is achieved when $r = 1$, $n_1 = g$, and $D_1 = k$. In this case, we have

$$\dim_k \text{End}(A) = g^2.$$

Thus, the maximum number of independent elements in $\text{End}(A)$ is $g^2$.
